original: Majjhima Nikāya 106
analyzed: majjhima nikāya
translated: Middle Length Discourses

original: Āneñjasappāyasutta
analyzed: āneñja sappāya sutta
translated: The Way to the Immovable

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā kurūsu viharati kammāsadhammaṁ nāma kurūnaṁ nigamo.
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā kurūsu viharati kammāsadhammam nāma kurūnam nigamaḥ
translated: On one occasion the Blessed One was dwelling among the Kurus at Kammāsadamma.

original: Tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi:
analyzed: tatra kho bhagavā bhikkhū āmantesi
translated: There the Blessed One addressed the bhikkhus thus:

original: “bhikkhavo”ti.
analyzed: bhikkhavaḥ ti
translated: “Bhikkhus!”

original: “Bhadante”ti te bhikkhū bhagavato paccassosuṁ.
analyzed: bhadanta iti te bhikkhū bhagavataḥ
translated: “Venerable sir!” those bhikkhus replied.

original: Bhagavā etadavoca:
analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca
translated: The Blessed One said this:

original: “Aniccā, bhikkhave, kāmā tucchā musā mosadhammā.
analyzed: aniccāḥ bhikkhave kāmāḥ tucchāḥ musāḥ mosa dhammāḥ
translated: “Bhikkhus, sensual pleasures are impermanent, hollow, false, deceptive;

original: Māyākatametaṁ, bhikkhave, bālalāpanaṁ.🔽Ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā, ye ca samparāyikā kāmā;
analyzed: bhikkhave  ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā ye ca samparāyikā kāmā
translated: they are a creation of the mind, a mere appearance. 🔽Sensual pleasures are both for this world and for the next world;

original: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā kāmasaññā—
analyzed: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāma saññā yā ca samparāyikā kāma saññā
translated: both sensual perceptions are for this world and for the next world;

original: ubhayametaṁ māradheyyaṁ, mārassesa visayo, mārassesa nivāpo, mārassesa gocaro.🔽Etthete pāpakā akusalā mānasā abhijjhāpi byāpādāpi sārambhāpi saṁvattanti.
analyzed: ubhayam etam māra dheyya mārassa isa visayaḥ mārassa isa nivāpaḥ mārassa isa gocaraḥ  ettha ete pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ mānasāḥ abhijjhā api byāpādā api sa ārambhā api savattanti
translated: both are Māra’s realm, Māra’s domain, Māra’s bait, Māra’s hunting ground. 🔽Evil unwholesome thoughts—of sensual desire, of ill will, and of cruelty—arise in a person in dependence on these two.

original: Teva ariyasāvakassa idhamanusikkhato antarāyāya sambhavanti.
analyzed: te iva ariya sāvakassa idham anusikkhataḥ antarāyāya sambhavanti
translated: They are an obstacle, a hindrance, a confinement, a shackle, a fetter, and a shackle of the mind.

original: Tatra, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: tatra bhikkhave ariya sāvakaḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: A noble disciple considers this:

original: ‘ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā, ye ca samparāyikā kāmā;
analyzed: ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā ye ca samparāyikā kāmā
translated: ‘There are sensual pleasures here and now and sensual pleasures in lives to come,

original: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā kāmasaññā—
analyzed: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāma saññā yā ca samparāyikā kāma saññā
translated: sensual perceptions here and now and sensual perceptions in lives to come.

original: ubhayametaṁ māradheyyaṁ, mārassesa visayo, mārassesa nivāpo, mārassesa gocaro.
analyzed: ubhayam etam māra dheyya mārassa isa visayaḥ mārassa isa nivāpaḥ mārassa isa gocaraḥ
translated: Both are Māra’s domain, Māra’s realm, Māra’s bait, Māra’s hunting ground.

original: Etthete pāpakā akusalā mānasā abhijjhāpi byāpādāpi sārambhāpi saṁvattanti,
analyzed: ettha ete pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ mānasāḥ abhijjhā api byāpādā api sa ārambhā api savattanti
translated: On both of them evil unwholesome thoughts — covetousness and ill will and presumption — arise,

original: teva ariyasāvakassa idhamanusikkhato antarāyāya sambhavanti.🔽Yannūnāhaṁ vipulena mahaggatena cetasā vihareyyaṁ abhibhuyya lokaṁ adhiṭṭhāya manasā.🔽Vipulena hi me mahaggatena cetasā viharato abhibhuyya lokaṁ adhiṭṭhāya manasā ye pāpakā akusalā mānasā abhijjhāpi byāpādāpi sārambhāpi te na bhavissanti.
analyzed: te iva ariya sāvakassa idham anusikkhataḥ antarāyāya sambhavanti  yat nūna aham vipulena mahaggatena cetasā vihareyyam abhibhuyya lokam adhiṭṭhāya manasā  vipulena hi me mahaggatena cetasā viharataḥ abhibhuyya lokam adhiṭṭhāya manasā ye pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ mānasāḥ abhijjhā api byāpādā api sa ārambhā api te na bhavissanti
translated: which are an obstacle for a noble disciple in training here.🔽Suppose I were to dwell with a mind well established in the four establishments of mindfulness.

original: Tesaṁ pahānā aparittañca me cittaṁ bhavissati appamāṇaṁ subhāvitan’ti.
analyzed: tesam pahānā aparittam ca me cittam bhavissati appamāṇam su bhāvitanti
translated: For when my mind is well established in the four establishments of mindfulness, then whatever evil unwholesome thoughts arise, they will be abandoned, and whatever evil unwholesome thoughts have arisen will be removed.’

original: Tassa evaṁpaṭipannassa tabbahulavihārino āyatane cittaṁ pasīdati.🔽Sampasāde sati etarahi vā āneñjaṁ samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā.
analyzed: tassa eva paṭipannassa tad bahula vihārinaḥ āyatane cittam pasīdati  sampasāde sati etarahi vā āneñjam samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā
translated: As he continues to develop this meditation, his mind becomes placid, malleable, and wieldy in regard to that object.🔽When the mind is placid, malleable, and wieldy in regard to that object, then the monk directs his mind to the attainment of the base of nothingness.

original: Ṭhānametaṁ vijjati yaṁ taṁsaṁvattanikaṁ viññāṇaṁ assa āneñjūpagaṁ.
analyzed: ṭhānam etam vijjati yat tasavattanikam viññāṇam assa āneñjūpaga
translated: It is possible that the monk’s mind becomes placid, malleable, and wieldy in regard to the base of nothingness.

original: Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, paṭhamā āneñjasappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati.
analyzed: bhikkhave paṭhamā āneñjasappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati
translated: This is declared to be the first way directed to the imperturbable.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave ariya sāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: “Again, a noble disciple considers thus:

original: ‘ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā, ye ca samparāyikā kāmā;
analyzed: ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā ye ca samparāyikā kāmā
translated: ‘There are sensual desires pertaining to the present life and there are sensual desires pertaining to future lives.

original: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā kāmasaññā;
analyzed: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāma saññā yā ca samparāyikā kāma saññā
translated: There is perception of sensual desires pertaining to the present life and there is perception of sensual desires pertaining to future lives.

original: yaṁ kiñci rūpaṁ sabbaṁ rūpaṁ cattāri ca mahābhūtāni, catunnañca mahābhūtānaṁ upādāyarūpan’ti.
analyzed: yam kiñci rūpam sabbam rūpam cattāri ca mahābhūtāni catunnam ca mahābhūtānam
translated: Whatever is material form is all four great elements and the material form derived from the four great elements.’

original: Tassa evaṁpaṭipannassa tabbahulavihārino āyatane cittaṁ pasīdati.
analyzed: tassa eva paṭipannassa tad bahula vihārinaḥ āyatane cittam pasīdati
translated: As he continues to develop this meditation, his mind becomes placid, malleable, and wieldy in regard to that object.

original: Sampasāde sati etarahi vā āneñjaṁ samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā.
analyzed: sampasāde sati etarahi vā āneñjam samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā
translated: When confidence has arisen, he either attains the imperturbable now or else he decides upon perfecting wisdom.

original: Ṭhānametaṁ vijjati yaṁ taṁsaṁvattanikaṁ viññāṇaṁ assa āneñjūpagaṁ.
analyzed: ṭhānam etam vijjati yat tasavattanikam viññāṇam assa āneñjūpaga
translated: With the breakup of the body, after death, his consciousness will head for the imperturbable.

original: Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, dutiyā āneñjasappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati.
analyzed: bhikkhave dutiyā āneñjasappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati
translated: This is the second way that is conducive to the imperturbable.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave ariya sāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: “Again, a noble disciple considers this:

analyzed: ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā ye ca samparāyikā kāmā
translated: ‘There are sensual pleasures here and now and sensual pleasures in lives to come,

original: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā kāmasaññā;🔽ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpā, ye ca samparāyikā rūpā;
analyzed: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāma saññā yā ca samparāyikā kāma saññā  ye ca diṭṭhadhammikāḥ rūpā ye ca samparāyikāḥ rūpā
translated: sensual perceptions here and now and sensual perceptions in lives to come,🔽visible forms here and now and visible forms in lives to come,

original: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā rūpasaññā—
analyzed: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpa saññā yā ca samparāyikā rūpa saññā
translated: and perceptions of forms here and now and perceptions of forms in lives to come.

original: ubhayametaṁ aniccaṁ.
analyzed: ubhayam etam anit ca
translated: Both are impermanent.

original: Yadaniccaṁ taṁ nālaṁ abhinandituṁ, nālaṁ abhivadituṁ, nālaṁ ajjhositun’ti.
analyzed: yat aniccam tam na alam abhinanditu na alam abhivaditu na alam ajjhositum
translated: What is impermanent is not worth relishing or welcoming or accepting or making much of.’

original: Tassa evaṁpaṭipannassa tabbahulavihārino āyatane cittaṁ pasīdati.
analyzed: tassa eva paṭipannassa tad bahula vihārinaḥ āyatane cittam pasīdati
translated: As he keeps on practicing in this way, his mind becomes clear, pure, and bright.

original: Sampasāde sati etarahi vā āneñjaṁ samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā.
analyzed: sampasāde sati etarahi vā āneñjam samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā
translated: When confidence has arisen, he either attains the imperturbable now or else he decides upon perfecting wisdom.

analyzed: ṭhānam etam vijjati yat tasavattanikam viññāṇam assa āneñjūpaga
translated: With the breakup of the body, after death, his consciousness will head for the imperturbable.

original: Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, tatiyā āneñjasappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati.
analyzed: bhikkhave tatiyā āneñjasappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati
translated: This is the third way that is conducive to the imperturbable.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:🔽‘ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā, ye ca samparāyikā kāmā;
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave ariya sāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati  ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā ye ca samparāyikā kāmā
translated: “Again, a noble disciple considers thus:

original: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā kāmasaññā;🔽ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpā, ye ca samparāyikā rūpā;
analyzed: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāma saññā yā ca samparāyikā kāma saññā  ye ca diṭṭhadhammikāḥ rūpā ye ca samparāyikāḥ rūpā
translated: ‘There are sensual pleasures here and now and sensual pleasures in lives to come, sensual perceptions here and now and sensual perceptions in lives to come,

original: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā rūpasaññā;
analyzed: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpa saññā yā ca samparāyikā rūpa saññā
translated: material forms here and now and material forms in lives to come, material perceptions here and now and material perceptions in lives to come,

original: yā ca āneñjasaññā—
analyzed: yā ca āneñja saññā
translated: and the perception of the imperturbable.

original: sabbā saññā.
analyzed: sabbā saññā
translated: All these are perceptions.

original: Yatthetā aparisesā nirujjhanti etaṁ santaṁ etaṁ paṇītaṁ—
analyzed: yattha itāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti etam santam etam paṇīta
translated: The stilling of all these perceptions, their fading away and cessation, is peaceful, sublime, an attainment beyond this world—

original: yadidaṁ ākiñcaññāyatanan’ti.
analyzed: yat idam ākiñcaññāyatanam ti
translated: namely, the base of nothingness.’

original: Tassa evaṁpaṭipannassa tabbahulavihārino āyatane cittaṁ pasīdati.
analyzed: tassa eva paṭipannassa tad bahula vihārinaḥ āyatane cittam pasīdati
translated: As he develops this perception, his mind becomes steadied in samādhi.

original: Sampasāde sati etarahi vā ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā.
analyzed: sampasāde sati etarahi vā ākiñcaññāyatanam samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā
translated: When confidence has arisen, he either attains to the base of nothingness or his mind is rightly released from the taints.

original: Ṭhānametaṁ vijjati yaṁ taṁsaṁvattanikaṁ viññāṇaṁ assa ākiñcaññāyatanūpagaṁ.
analyzed: ṭhānam etam vijjati yam tasavattanikam viññāṇam assa ākiñcañña āyatana upaga
translated: It is possible that his consciousness follows along with that sign, and so after death he reappears in the company of the gods of the base of nothingness.

original: Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, paṭhamā ākiñcaññāyatanasappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati.
analyzed: ayam bhikkhave paṭhamā ākiñcaññāyatana sappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati
translated: This is declared to be the first way directed to the base of nothingness.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave ariya sāvakaḥ arañña gataḥ vā rukkha mūla gataḥ vā suññāgāra gataḥ vā iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: “Again, bhikkhus, a noble disciple considers this:

original: ‘suññamidaṁ attena vā attaniyena vā’ti.🔽Tassa evaṁpaṭipannassa tabbahulavihārino āyatane cittaṁ pasīdati.🔽Sampasāde sati etarahi vā ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā.
analyzed: suññam idam attena vā attaniyena vā ati  tassa eva paṭipannassa tad bahula vihārinaḥ āyatane cittam pasīdati  sampasāde sati etarahi vā ākiñcaññāyatanam samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā
translated: ‘This is peaceful, this is sublime, that is, the stilling of all formations, the relinquishing of all acquisitions, the destruction of craving, dispassion, cessation, Nibbana.’🔽As he considers this, his mind becomes placid, and by means of this placidity he attains to the base of nothingness or his mind is rightly released from the taints.

original: Ṭhānametaṁ vijjati yaṁ taṁsaṁvattanikaṁ viññāṇaṁ assa ākiñcaññāyatanūpagaṁ.
analyzed: ṭhānam etam vijjati yam tasavattanikam viññāṇam assa ākiñcañña āyatana upaga
translated: It is possible that his consciousness follows along with that sign, and so after death he reappears in the company of the gods of the base of nothingness.

original: Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, dutiyā ākiñcaññāyatanasappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati.
analyzed: bhikkhave dutiyā ākiñcaññāyatana sappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati
translated: This is the second way directed to the base of nothingness that is peaceful and sublime, a wonderful open space, and is regarded as a pleasant abiding.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave ariya sāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: “Again, a noble disciple considers thus:

original: ‘nāhaṁ kvacani kassaci kiñcanatasmiṁ, na ca mama kvacani kismiñci kiñcanaṁ natthī’ti.🔽Tassa evaṁpaṭipannassa tabbahulavihārino āyatane cittaṁ pasīdati.
analyzed: na aham kvacani kassaci na ca mama kvacani kismiñci kiñcanam natthi iti  tassa eva paṭipannassa tad bahula vihārinaḥ āyatane cittam pasīdati
translated: ‘I am not anywhere subject to anyone in any way at all, nor is there anything anywhere subject to me.🔽As he continues to reflect in this way, his mind becomes placid, and being placid, it becomes concentrated and one-pointed.

original: Sampasāde sati etarahi vā ākiñcaññāyatanaṁ samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā.🔽Ṭhānametaṁ vijjati yaṁ taṁsaṁvattanikaṁ viññāṇaṁ assa ākiñcaññāyatanūpagaṁ.
analyzed: sampasāde sati etarahi vā ākiñcaññāyatanam samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā  ṭhānam etam vijjati yam tasavattanikam viññāṇam assa ākiñcañña āyatana upaga
translated: When this is so, he either attains to the base of nothingness now or else he decides upon perfecting wisdom.🔽It is possible that his consciousness follows along with that attainment and is inclined towards the base of nothingness.

original: Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, tatiyā ākiñcaññāyatanasappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati.
analyzed: bhikkhave tatiyā ākiñcaññāyatana sappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati
translated: This is the third way directed to the base of nothingness that is peaceful and sublime, a wonderful open space, and is regarded as a pleasant abiding.

original: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:🔽‘ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā, ye ca samparāyikā kāmā;
analyzed: puna capara bhikkhave ariya sāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati  ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā ye ca samparāyikā kāmā
translated: “Again, a noble disciple considers thus:🔽‘There are sensual desires that are visible here and now and sensual desires that are reported elsewhere.

original: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā kāmasaññā;
analyzed: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāma saññā yā ca samparāyikā kāma saññā
translated: There are sensual desires that are visible here and now and sensual desires that are reported elsewhere.

original: ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpā, ye ca samparāyikā rūpā;🔽yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā rūpasaññā;
analyzed: ye ca diṭṭhadhammikāḥ rūpā ye ca samparāyikāḥ rūpā  yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpa saññā yā ca samparāyikā rūpa saññā
translated: the forms of the present and the future,🔽the perceptions of the forms of the present and the future,

analyzed: yā ca āneñja saññā yā ca ākiñcañña āyatana saññā
translated: the perception of the base of nothingness and the perception of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception,

analyzed: sabbā saññā  yattha itāḥ aparisesāḥ nirujjhanti etam santam etam paṇīta
translated: all perceptions cease without remainder.🔽This is peaceful, this is sublime,

translated: namely, the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.’

analyzed: tassa eva paṭipannassa tad bahula vihārinaḥ āyatane cittam pasīdati  sampasāde sati etarahi vā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanam samāpajjati paññāya vā adhimuccati kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā
translated: When he practices like this and frequently abides thus, his mind becomes placid in regard to the bases.🔽When there is placidity, he either attains to the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception now or else he decides upon perfecting wisdom.

original: Ṭhānametaṁ vijjati yaṁ taṁsaṁvattanikaṁ viññāṇaṁ assa nevasaññānāsaññāyatanūpagaṁ.
analyzed: ṭhānam etam vijjati yam tasa vattanikam viññāṇam assa nevasaññānāsaññāyatana upaga
translated: It is possible that his consciousness follows after that perception and heads towards that perception, and that his consciousness heads towards the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

original: Ayaṁ, bhikkhave, nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyatī”ti.
analyzed: aya bhikkhave nevasaññānāsaññāyatana sappāyā paṭipadā akkhāyati iti
translated: This is the way, bhikkhus, that leads to the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte āyasmai ānandaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, the venerable Ananda said to the Blessed One:

original: “idha, bhante, bhikkhu evaṁ paṭipanno hoti:
analyzed: idha bhante bhikkhu evam paṭipannaḥ hoti
translated: “Venerable sir, here a bhikkhu abides resolved upon and pervading an area with a pure radiance:

original: ‘no cassa, no ca me siyā; na bhavissati, na me bhavissati; yadatthi yaṁ, bhūtaṁ—taṁ pajahāmī’ti.
analyzed: no ca assa no ca me siyā na bhavissati na me bhavissati yat atthi bhūtatam pajahāmi iti
translated: ‘I am not, I will not be, what was I in the past? What will I be in the future? What is my self? Is my self without self?

original: Evaṁ upekkhaṁ paṭilabhati.
analyzed: evam upekkham paṭilabhati
translated: He gains equanimity in regard to it.

original: Parinibbāyeyya nu kho so, bhante, bhikkhu na vā parinibbāyeyyā”ti?
analyzed: parinibbāyeyya nu kho so bhante bhikkhu na vā parinibbāyeyya ati
translated: Could that monk attain final Nibbāna, or not?”

original: “Apetthekacco, ānanda, bhikkhu parinibbāyeyya, apetthekacco bhikkhu na parinibbāyeyyā”ti.
analyzed: apa ittha ekaccaḥ ānanda bhikkhu parinibbāyeyya apa ittha ekaccaḥ bhikkhu na parinibbāyeyya ati
translated: “Some could, Ānanda, and some could not.”

original: “Ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo yenapetthekacco bhikkhu parinibbāyeyya, apetthekacco bhikkhu na parinibbāyeyyā”ti?
analyzed: kaḥ nu kho bhante hetu kaḥ paccayaḥ yena pa itthā ekaccaḥ bhikkhu parinibbāyeyya apa itthā ekaccaḥ bhikkhu na parinibbāyeyya ati
translated: “What is the cause, what is the reason why some could and some could not?”

original: “Idhānanda, bhikkhu evaṁ paṭipanno hoti:
analyzed: idha ānanda bhikkhu evam paṭipannaḥ hoti
translated: “Ānanda, a monk practices like this:

original: ‘no cassa, no ca me siyā; na bhavissati, na me bhavissati; yadatthi, yaṁ bhūtaṁ—taṁ pajahāmī’ti.
analyzed: no ca assa no ca me siyā na bhavissati na me bhavissati yat atthi yam bhūtatam pajahāmi iti
translated: ‘I am not, I will not be, what was I in the past? What will I be in the future? What is my self? Is my self without self?

original: Evaṁ upekkhaṁ paṭilabhati.
analyzed: evam upekkham paṭilabhati
translated: He gains equanimity in regard to it.

original: So taṁ upekkhaṁ abhinandati, abhivadati, ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: so tam upekkham abhinandati abhivadati ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati
translated: He delights in that equanimity, welcomes it, and remains holding to it.

original: Tassa taṁ upekkhaṁ abhinandato abhivadato ajjhosāya tiṭṭhato tannissitaṁ hoti viññāṇaṁ tadupādānaṁ.
analyzed: tassa tam upekkham abhinandataḥ abhivadataḥ ajjhosāya tiṭṭhataḥ tad nissitam hoti viññāṇam tad upādāna
translated: As he delights in that equanimity, welcomes it, & remains attached to it, consciousness becomes dependent on it.

original: Saupādāno, ānanda, bhikkhu na parinibbāyatī”ti.
analyzed: sa aupādānaḥ ānanda bhikkhu na parinibbāyati iti
translated: A bhikkhu who has clinging does not attain Nibbana.”

original: “Kahaṁ pana so, bhante, bhikkhu upādiyamāno upādiyatī”ti?
analyzed: kaham pana saḥ bhante bhikkhu upādiyamānaḥ upādiyati iti
translated: “But, venerable sir, where does a bhikkhu who has clinging cling?”

original: “Nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ, ānandā”ti.
analyzed: na ivasaññā nāsañña āyatane ānanda ati
translated: “In the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception, Ananda.”

original: “Upādānaseṭṭhaṁ kira so, bhante, bhikkhu upādiyamāno upādiyatī”ti?
analyzed: upādāna seṭṭham kira saḥ bhante bhikkhu upādiyamānaḥ upādiyati iti
translated: “So it seems that the bhikkhu who has clinging clings to the best object of clinging.”

original: “Upādānaseṭṭhañhi so, ānanda, bhikkhu upādiyamāno upādiyati.
analyzed: upādāna seṭṭham hi saḥ ānanda bhikkhu upādiyamānaḥ upādiyati
translated: “The bhikkhu who has clinging clings to the best object of clinging.

original: Upādānaseṭṭhañhetaṁ, ānanda, yadidaṁ—
analyzed: upādāna seṭṭhan ha itas ānanda yat idam
translated: For this, Ananda, is the best object of clinging, namely,

original: nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṁ.
analyzed: na ivasaññā nāsañña āyatana
translated: the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception.

original: Idhānanda, bhikkhu evaṁ paṭipanno hoti:
analyzed: idha ānanda bhikkhu evam paṭipannaḥ hoti
translated: “Here, Ananda, a bhikkhu practises equanimity, thinking:

original: ‘no cassa, no ca me siyā; na bhavissati, na me bhavissati; yadatthi, yaṁ bhūtaṁ—taṁ pajahāmī’ti.
analyzed: no ca assa no ca me siyā na bhavissati na me bhavissati yat atthi yam bhūtatam pajahāmi iti
translated: ‘This has come to be’—thus he abides, and he abides contemplating its fading away.

original: Evaṁ upekkhaṁ paṭilabhati.
analyzed: evam upekkham paṭilabhati
translated: He attains equanimity that is unshakable.

original: So taṁ upekkhaṁ nābhinandati, nābhivadati, na ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: so tam upekkham na abhinandati na abhivadati na ajjhosāya tiṭṭhati
translated: He does not delight in that equanimity, welcome it, or remain attached to it.

original: Tassa taṁ upekkhaṁ anabhinandato anabhivadato anajjhosāya tiṭṭhato na tannissitaṁ hoti viññāṇaṁ na tadupādānaṁ.
analyzed: tassa tam upekkham an abhinandataḥ an abhivadataḥ an ajjhosāya tiṭṭhataḥ na tat nissitam hoti viññāṇam na tat upādāna
translated: When he does not delight in that equanimity, does not welcome it, and does not remain holding to it, his consciousness does not become dependent on it and cling to it.

original: Anupādāno, ānanda, bhikkhu parinibbāyatī”ti.
analyzed: anupādānaḥ ānanda bhikkhu parinibbāyati iti
translated: A bhikkhu who does not cling does not tremble.”

original: “Acchariyaṁ, bhante, abbhutaṁ, bhante.
analyzed: acchariya bhante abbhuta bhante
translated: “It is wonderful, venerable sir, it is marvellous!

original: Nissāya nissāya kira no, bhante, bhagavatā oghassa nittharaṇā akkhātā.
analyzed: nissāya nissāya kira naḥ bhante bhagavatā oghassa nittharaṇā akkhātā
translated: The Blessed One has indeed declared the crossing of the flood in dependence on a support.

original: Katamo pana, bhante, ariyo vimokkho”ti?
analyzed: katamaḥ pana bhante ariyaḥ vimokkhaḥ ti
translated: But, venerable sir, what is the noble liberation?”

original: “Idhānanda, bhikkhu ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:🔽‘ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā, ye ca samparāyikā kāmā;
analyzed: idha ānanda bhikkhu ariya sāvakaḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati  ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmā ye ca samparāyikā kāmā
translated: “Here, Ananda, a noble disciple considers thus:

original: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāmasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā kāmasaññā;
analyzed: yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā kāma saññā yā ca samparāyikā kāma saññā
translated: ‘There are sensual pleasures here and now and sensual pleasures in lives to come, sensual pleasures of form and formless sensual pleasures.🔽But whatever sensual pleasures there are, they are all impermanent, suffering, and subject to change.

original: ye ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpā, ye ca samparāyikā rūpā;🔽yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpasaññā, yā ca samparāyikā rūpasaññā;
analyzed: ye ca diṭṭhadhammikāḥ rūpā ye ca samparāyikāḥ rūpā  yā ca diṭṭhadhammikā rūpa saññā yā ca samparāyikā rūpa saññā
translated: There are material forms here and now and material forms in lives to come.🔽But whatever material forms there are, they are all impermanent, suffering, and subject to change.

original: yā ca āneñjasaññā, yā ca ākiñcaññāyatanasaññā, yā ca nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasaññā—🔽esa sakkāyo yāvatā sakkāyo.
analyzed: yā ca āneñja saññā yā ca ākiñcañña āyatana saññā yā ca nevasaññānāsaññāyatana saññā 🔽esa sakkāyaḥ yāvatā sakkāyaḥ
translated: And whatever perceptions there are—perceptions of the imperturbable, perceptions of the base of nothingness, perceptions of the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception—🔽they are all impermanent, suffering, and subject to change.

original: Etaṁ amataṁ yadidaṁ anupādā cittassa vimokkho.
analyzed: etam amatam yat idam anupādā cittassa vimokkho
translated: This is the Deathless, namely, the freedom of mind that comes through letting go.

original: Iti, kho, ānanda, desitā mayā āneñjasappāyā paṭipadā, desitā ākiñcaññāyatanasappāyā
analyzed: iti kho ānanda desitā mayā āneñja sappāyā paṭipadā desitā ākiñcaññāyatana sappāyā
translated: “Thus, Ānanda, the way directed to the imperturbable has been taught by me, the way directed to the base of nothingness has been taught by me,

original: paṭipadā, desitā nevasaññānāsaññāyatanasappāyā paṭipadā, desitā nissāya nissāya oghassa
analyzed: paṭipadā desitā nevasaññā nāsañña āyatana sappāyā paṭipadā desitā nissāya nissāya oghassa
translated: the way directed to the base of neither-perception-nor-non-perception has been taught by me, the crossing of the flood has been taught by me without any hoarding on the part of the disciple,

original: nittharaṇā, desito ariyo vimokkho.
analyzed: nittharaṇā desitaḥ ariyaḥ vimokkho
translated: and the noble liberation has been taught by me.

original: Yaṁ kho, ānanda, satthārā karaṇīyaṁ sāvakānaṁ hitesinā anukampakena anukampaṁ upādāya, kataṁ vo taṁ mayā.
analyzed: yam khalu ānanda satthārā karaṇīyam sāvakānam hita īsinā anukampakena anukampam upādāya katam vaḥ tam mayā
translated: “Ānanda, whatever should be done by a Tathāgata for the welfare of the monks, that has been done by me.

original: Etāni, ānanda, rukkhamūlāni, etāni suññāgārāni. Jhāyathānanda, mā pamādattha, mā pacchā vippaṭisārino ahuvattha. Ayaṁ vo amhākaṁ anusāsanī’”ti.
analyzed: etāni ānanda rukkha mūlāni etāni suññāgārāni jhāyatha ānanda mā pamādattha mā pacchā vippaṭisārinaḥ ahuvattha ayam vaḥ amhākam anusāsanī iti
translated: Here, Ānanda, are the roots of trees. Here are empty huts. Meditate, Ānanda, do not delay, or else you will regret it later. This is our instruction to you.”

original: Idamavoca bhagavā.
analyzed: idam avoca bhagavān
translated: This is what the Blessed One said.

original: Attamano āyasmā ānando bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandīti.🔽Āneñjasappāyasuttaṁ niṭṭhitaṁ chaṭṭhaṁ.
analyzed: āyasmai ānandaḥ bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinandi iti 🔽āneñjasappāya suttam niṭṭhitam chaṭṭha
translated: Pleased, the venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Blessed One said.🔽The Sutta on the Way Directed to the Imperturbable is finished.
